intro: Uragoga consanguinea, commonly known as the blood vine, is a climbing plant native to tropical regions of Africa. It belongs to the family Menispermaceae and is characterized by its woody stems and compound leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers followed by fleshy, red berries that are edible. Its roots and leaves are used in traditional medicine for their purported anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties. Uragoga consanguinea thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in secondary forests.
